S4.T1.1.caption:
The performance of Wait- -SiLLM+SFT when using different training data for SFT. ‚ÄòFull-Sentence‚Äô denotes full-sentence pairs. ‚ÄòSiMT‚Äô represents the SiMT data corresponding to the Wait-5 policy.
The experiments are performed on the De En task.
S4.T1.1.table:
SFT Data k𝑘kitalic_k AL BLEU
Full-Sentence 5 5.11 31.30
SiMT 5 5.43 1.00
references: Previous SiMT methods (Ma et¬†al., 2020; Zhang and Feng, 2022) have found that SiMT models excel in SiMT during inference only when trained to generate translations based on partial source sentences. To validate this in SiLLM, we construct the SiMT data corresponding to the Wait-5 policy to fine-tune the LLM and compare it with our method. As depicted in Table 1, full-sentence data proves more effective in stimulating the ability of LLM to translate based on incomplete source information compared to SiMT data corresponding to the Wait-kùëòkitalic_k policy. We find that the translations generated by LLM deviate from the source sentences and lack fluency after using SiMT data for SFT. We attribute this issue to the fact that the SiMT data corresponding to the Wait-kùëòkitalic_k policy fails to consider the semantic equivalence between the source and target, resulting in the failure of SFT. The construction method for the SiMT data is detailed in the Appendix B.

S5.T2.2.caption: Comparison of inference speed among different SiMT methods. ‚ÄòSpeed‚Äô is measured by the number of words generated per second (i.e., word/s). The experiments are performed on the De En task.
S5.T2.2.table:
Method AL BLEU Speed (↑)↑(\uparrow)( ↑ )
Wait-k𝑘kitalic_k 3.85 25.83 107.97
HMT 4.73 29.10 32.47
HMT-SiLLM+SFT 4.2 30.60 9.94
references: We evaluate the inference speed of various SiMT methods using NVIDIA GeForce RTX 3090 and present the results in Table 2. The Wait-kùëòkitalic_k method exhibits the poorest performance but attains the highest inference speed due to its simplistic architecture. Although slower than the Wait-kùëòkitalic_k, HMT demonstrates a significant improvement in performance. Our approach, incorporating HMT and LLM, achieves a slower inference speed but optimal performance. Considering the application scenarios of the SiMT task, our method can generate 9 words per second, fully meeting practical requirements. Moreover, our method can benefit from acceleration on more advanced hardware, resulting in faster inference speeds.

A3.T3.5.caption: Settings of HMT-SiLLM+SFT.
A3.T3.5.table:
Hyperparameters WMT15 De→normal-→\rightarrow→En MuST-C En→normal-→\rightarrow→De
LLM Base_model Base_model Llama2-7B-chat
LoRA lora_r 8 8
lora_alpha 16 16
lora_dropout 0.05 0.05
lora_target_modules q_proj, k_proj, v_proj, o_proj
Training Details batch_size 128 128
micro_batch_size 4 4
learning_rate 1e-4 1e-4
HMT Encoder encoder_layers 6 6
encoder_embed_dim 512 512
encoder_ffn_embed_dim 2048 1024
encoder_attention_heads 8 4
Decoder decoder_layers 6 6
decoder_embed_dim 512 512
decoder_ffn_embed_dim 2048 1024
decoder_attention_heads 8 4
Training Details dropout 0.3 0.3
optimizer adam adam
adam_β𝛽\betaitalic_β (0.9, 0.98) (0.9, 0.98)
clip_norm 0 0
lr 5e-4 5e-4
lr_scheduler inverse_sqrt inverse_sqrt
warmup_updates 4000 4000
warmup_init_lr 1e-7 1e-7
weight_decay 0.0 0.0
label_smoothing 0.1 0.1
max_tokens 8192×\times×4 8192×\times×4
references: In this section, we primarily present the experimental setup for HMT-SiLLM+SFT. The settings of HMT-SiLLM+SFT are shown in Table 3. As shown in Figure 7, we also provide the prompt template for the LLM, along with examples for both De‚Üí‚Üí\rightarrow‚ÜíEn and En‚Üí‚Üí\rightarrow‚ÜíDe tasks.
